content:
I edited the contribution as follows:

Input
* I added the variable name [[s]].

Output
* I changed "alpha characters" to "English letters".

* I added "only" to the end.

Constraints
* I changed "Text will be printable ASCII" to "[[s]] contains printable ASCII characters only."

Cases
* I changed the title of Test 4 and Validator 4 from "w o w" to "ALL UPPER".

* I added Test 5 and Validator 5 ("Rhythm") to cover characters used in previous tests but not in previous validators or vice versa.

I just played it in Reverse Mode. Unfortunately, the test cases are not similar to the validator cases, allowing my code to pass all the test cases but not the validator cases. I suggest you to modify the test cases to ensure that this situation doesn't happen.
In the meantime, I remove your puzzle from the Reverse Mode category.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple but classic.
Not that straitforward with regex

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The instructions are clear and the problem fits into Clash of Code.
I can see this challenge would be a lot of fun in "Fastest" mode.
This one is great for Clash of Code! I appreciate that the requirements are clear.

I'm confused

>> Remove all characters from the given string, except for letters and spaces.
This statement is contradicting to the examples.
It is a little on the easy side but it's not a bad one, maybe better for code golf ?
first contrib! a simple CoC that tests a little bit of regex knowledge. fairly simple, and can be solved in a couple lines in most languages.

in facts it is trivial and solvable one line in most languages (17 chars in bash)
and i'm almost sure it already exists

Each test and its validator look pretty similar to me. I've re-enabled Reverse mode.

Could you explain where a test is not similar to its validator?

Sure! Without knowing the rule, I understood that some characters needed to be removed, and I manually came up with the following solution in Python:
print(''.join(e for e in s if e not in ',!_()?=0123456789'))
which passes all the test cases. However, some characters (namely those in '.+-*{}') are only present in validators.

I agree that in classic mode, this solution would be considered hardcoded. But in reverse mode, that's not so clear.

In hindsight, I will trust your experience of Clash of Code if you consider that the generalization is part of the exercise. That seems quite obvious afterwards, but it was a surprise to pass all the test cases and only 25% of the validators.

Thank you for your explanation!

I think it would also help by considering how many other players failed in the Reverse mode when assessing whether Reverse mode should be enabled.
Now that I understand the issue, I'll try to swap or modify a few cases later today. Thanks again.

most clashes are pretty trivial if you know what to do. this one is only trivial if you know regex, but can be solved other ways too. I searched a bit and couldn't find information about existing CoCs, but if you know where I can go to check if its a duplicate, that would be helpful.
